choices.text: Sympathetic chain- Posterior intercostal vein- Superior intercostal artery- 1st thoracic nerve
1st thoracic nerve- Superior intercostal artery- Posterior intercostal vein- Sympathetic chain
Posterior intercostal artery- Posterior intercostal vein- Sympathetic chain-1st thoracic nerve
Posterior intercostal vein- Superior intercostal artery- 1st thoracic nerve- Sympathetic chain

questions.text: Following structure is related to neck of 1st rib from medial to lateral side are ?
questions.solution:
First Rib :

  • Shortest, broadest and most curved rib.
  • Shaft is not twisted. No costal groove.
  • Flattened from above downwards so it has superior and inferior surfaces.
  • Upper surface has two grooves separated by ridge

Key take aways :

The neck of 1st rib related medial to lateral side to : (Mnemonics : Chain pulling VAN)

  • Sympathetic Chain
  • Posterior intercostal Vein
  • Superior intercostal Artery
  • 1st thoracic Nerve

questions.text: Which of the following pair is incorrect for joints and its type ?
questions.solution:
The various joints of thorax and their types are as follows :

  • Manubriosternal joint : Secondary cartilaginous joint
  • Costovertebral joint : Plane synovial joint
  • Costotransverse joint : Plane synovial joint
  • Costochondral joint : Primary cartilaginous joint
  • 1st Chondrosternal joint : Primary cartilaginous,
  • 2nd to 7th Chondrosternal joint: Plane synovial joint
  • Interchondral joint : Plane synovial joint
  • Intervertebral disc : Secondary cartilaginous joint

choices.text: Arch of aorta begins and ends at this level
Azygos vein arches over root of right lung to end in superior vena cava
Intervertebral disc between T5 and T6
Trachea bifurcates into right and left principal bronchi

questions.text: All of the following structure are present at marked body surface landmark except
questions.solution:
The marked surface landmark is Sternal angle.

The Sternal angle is an important surface landmark for many anatomical events occurs at this level. These are :

  • Second costal cartilage articulate with the sternum hence used for counting the ribs
  • Intervertebral disc between T4 and T5
  • Plane separate superior and inferior mediastinum
  • Ascending aorta ends at this level
  • Arch of aorta begins and ends at this level
  • Descending aorta begins at this level
  • Trachea bifurcates into two principal bronchi
  • Pulmonary trunk divides into right and left pulmonary arteries
  • Upper border of heart lies at this level
  • Azygos vein arches over root of right lung to end in superior vena cava

Key takeaways: The sternal angle is a key landmark for the second costal cartilage, T4-T5 intervertebral disc, beginning of the descending aorta, bifurcation of the trachea, division of the pulmonary trunk, upper border of the heart, and the arch of the azygos vein into the superior vena cava.

choices.text: Bucket handle movement is produced by vertebrochondral ribs
Pump handle movements is produced by vertebrosternal ribs
Bucket handle movements increases the transverse diameter of thoracic cavity
Pump handle movement increase the vertical diameter of thoracic cavity

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect for respiratory movements ?
questions.solution:
Respiratory movements :

The lungs expand during the inspiration and retract during expiration. These movements are governed by the following factors :

  1. Alteration in the capacity of thorax are brought by movements of the thoracic wall.
  2. Elastic recoil of pulmonary alveoli and of thoracic wall expels air from lungs.

Pump handle Movements :

  • Occurs in the vertebrosternal ribs.
  • Slight movement at vertebral end of rib are magnified at anterior end
  • Along with up and down movement of 2nd to 6th ribs, the body of sternum also moves.
  • The anteroposterior diameter of thorax is increased.

Bucket handle movements :

  • Occurs at vertebrochondral ribs
  • The middle of shaft of rib lies at lower level than plane passing two ends
  • During elevation of rib, the shaft moves outwards.
  • The transverse diameter of thorax is increased.

Key takeaways: Respiratory movements include lung expansion and retraction, with pump handle movements increasing the anteroposterior diameter of the thorax at vertebra sternal ribs and bucket handle movements increasing the transverse diameter at vertebra chondral ribs.

questions.text: Which of the following match is correct for parts of Parietal pleura as shown in the given image ?
questions.solution:
Pleura : is a Serous membrane which is lined by mesothelium.

There are two pleural sac , one on either side of mediastinum.

Each pleural sac is invaginated from medial side by lung, so that it has outer layer , the parietal pleura and an inner layer, the visceral or pulmonary pleura.

Pulmonary pleura :

  • covers the surfaces and fissures of the lung except at hilum.
  • Firmly adherent to the lung and cannot be separated.
  • Supplied by autonomic nerves (sympathetic : T2-T5. Parasympathetic : Vagus)

Parietal pleura : Supplied by intercostal and phrenic nerves.

It has 4 parts :

  • Cervical : covers the apex of lung.
  • Costal : lines the thoracic wall.
  • Mediastinal : lines the mediastinum.
  • Diaphragmatic : lines the superior aspect of diaphragm.

choices.text: 1st intercostal space in midaxillary line
2nd intercostal space in anterior axillary line
4th intercostal space in anterior axillary line
6th intercostal space in midaxillary line

questions.text: A 40 years old female visited to hospital with complaint of sudden onset of chest pain and shortness of breath. On auscultation, the doctor noticed absence of breath sound over left lung. Chest x ray revealed presence of pleural effusion. What is the most preferred site for pleural tap ?
questions.solution:
Normally , the pleural cavity contains only 5-10 ml of clear fluid that lubricates the pleural surfaces to allow their smooth movements without friction.

The excessive accumulation of fluid in the pleural cavity is called pleural effusion. It occurs due to inflammation of pleura.

The pleural effusion leads to decreased expansion of the lung on the side of effusion. Clinically it can be detected with decreased breath sounds and dullness on percussion on the site of effusion.

When a small quantity of fluid is accumulates in the Costodiaphragmatic recess, the angle is obliterated. It is seen as a radiopaque shadow with a fluid line in chest X ray.

Pleural tap/ Thoracocentesis :

  • It is a procedure by which an excess fluid is aspirated from the pleural cavity.
  • It is performed with the patient in sitting position.
  • The needle is inserted in the 6th intercostal space in midaxillary line.
  • The needle is inserted into lower part of intercostal space along the upper border of rib to avoid injury to intercostal nerve and vessels.

choices.text: It is a beaded appearance due to many valves
It enter thorax through vena caval opening of diaphragm
It ends by opening into junction of left subclavian & left internal jugular vein
It ascend through posterior mediastinum crossing from right to left

questions.text: Which of the following statements are incorrect for marked strucutre ?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is Thoracic duct.

Thoracic duct :

  • It is largest lymphatic vessel in body.
  • Extends from upper part of abdomen to lower part of neck.
  • 45 cm long
  • It has beaded appearance because of many valves in its lumen.
  • Begins as continuous of cisterna chyli near T12 vertebra and enters into thorax through aortic opening of the diaphragm.
  • It ascends in posterior mediastinum and crosses from right left side at T5 level.
  • In neck, it arches at C7 level and end by opening into junction of left subclavian and left jugular vein.

Key takeaways :

questions.text: All of the following are constrictions of oesophagus except
questions.solution:
Oesophagus :

  • It is narrow muscular tube between pharynx and stomach.
  • It extends from lower part of neck to upper part of abdomen.
  • It is about 25 cm long.
  • It begins in the neck at lower border of cricoid cartilage.
  • It descends in front of vertebral column through superior and posterior part of mediastinum and pierces the diaphragm at T10 vertebra.
  • It ends by opening into stomach at its cardiac end at T11 vertebra level.

Key takeaways :

The oesophagus shows 4 constrictions :

  • At its beginning, crossed by cricopharyngeus. 15 cm from the incisor teeth
  • Crossed by aortic arch, 22.5 cm from incisor teeth
  • Crossed by left bronchus, 27.5 cm from incisor teeth
  • Pierces the diaphragm, 37.5 cm from incisor teeth

questions.text: Which of the following match is incorrect for veins of heart ?
questions.solution:
The coronary sinus is the largest vein of the heart.

It is situated in left posterior coronary sulcus.

It ends by opening into posterior wall of the right atrium.

It receives the following tributaries :

  • Great cardiac vein
  • Middle cardiac vein
  • Small cardiac vein
  • Posterior vein of the left ventricle
  • Oblique vein of left atrium of Marshall
  • Right marginal vein

The anterior cardiac vein : 3 to 4 in number on anterior wall of right ventricle and opens into right atrium through its anterior wall

Venae cordis Minimi : Smallest cardiac vein that opens directly into four chamber of heart.

Key takeaways: anterior cardiac vein is not tributary of coronary sinus.

questions.text: All of the following are branches of left coronary artery except
questions.solution:
Left coronary artery

It arises from the left posterior aortic sinus.

It runs forwards and to left and emerges between pulmonary trunk and left auricle.

It gives anterior interventricular branch and continue as Circumflex artery.

It winds round left border of the heart and continue in left posterior coronary sulcus.

Near posterior interventricular groove it terminates by anastomosing with right coronary artery.

Branches :

  1. Large branches : Anterior interventricular , Branches to diaphragmatic surfaces of left ventricle including large diagonal branch.
  2. Small branches : Left Atrial, Pulmonary and Terminal

Key takeaways: The right coronary artery (RCA) supplies the right atrium, right ventricle, and posterior interventricular septum, while the left coronary artery (LCA) supplies the left atrium, left ventricle, anterior interventricular septum, and includes the LAD and circumflex branches.

choices.text: Pulmonary : 2nd left intercostal space near sternum
Aortic : 2nd right intercostal space near sternum
Mitral : 4th left intercostal space , 9 cm from sternum
Tricuspid : Right half of lower end of body of sternum

questions.text: Which of the following pair is incorrect for cardiac valves and its auscultatory areas ?
questions.solution:
The sound arising in relation to a particular valve are best heard not directly over the valve, but at areas situated some distance away from the valve in direction of blood flow through it. These are called auscultatory areas.

The following are the valves and their auscultatory areas:

questions.text: Which of the following match is incorrect for Mediastinal impression of right lung ?
questions.solution:
The marked 4 is impression for Oesophagus.

The Strucutre related to Mediastinal surface of right lung are as follow :

  • Right atrium and auricle
  • A small part of right ventricle
  • Superior vena cava
  • Lower part of right brachiocephalic vein
  • Azygos vein
  • Oesophagus
  • Inferior vena cava
  • Trachea
  • Right vagus nerve
  • Right phrenic nerve

choices.text: It is aerated by secondary lobar bronchi
It is anatomical, functional and surgical sector of lung
There are 10 segments in each lung

questions.text: All of the following statements is correct for Bronchopulmonary segments except
questions.solution:
Bronchopulmonary segment :

  • These are well defined anatomical, functional and surgical sectors of the lung.
  • Each one is aerated by a tertiary or segmental bronchus.
  • They are 10 in number in each lung.
  • Each segment is pyramidal in shape with its apex directed towards the root of the lung.
  • Each segment has a segmental bronchus, segmental artery, autonomic nerves and lymph vessels.
  • The segmental vein lies in the connective tissue between adjacent Bronchopulmonary segments.
  • Bronchopulmonary segment is not a bronchovascular segment because it does not have its own vein.

Key takeaways: Bronchopulmonary segments are 10 pyramid-shaped functional lung units, each supplied by a segmental bronchus and artery, with veins located between segments.

choices.text: 5th to 11th left posterior intercostal vein

questions.text: All of the following are tributaries of marked vein except
questions.solution:
The marked vein is Azygos vein.

Azygos vein:

  • Drain the thoracic wall and upper lumbar region.
  • It forms the important channel connecting superior and inferior vena cava.
  • Formed by union of lumbar Azygos , right Subcostal and right ascending lumbar veins.
  • It enters the thorax by passing through aortic opening of diaphragm.
  • It ascends up to 4th thoracic vertebra where it arches forwards over root of right lung and ends by joining superior vena cava.

Tributaries:

  • Right superior intercostal vein
  • 5th to 11th right posterior intercostal veins
  • Hemiazygos vein
  • Accessory Hemiazygos vein
  • Right bronchial vein
  • Several oesophageal, Mediastinal, pericardial veins

questions.text: All of the following form the boundaries of Triangle of Koch except
questions.solution:
Triangle of Koch : It is bounded by

  • Ostium of coronary sinus
  • Septal leaflet of tricuspid valve
  • Tendon of Todaro.

AV node lies at the apex of this triangle.

Along the right border of atrium, there is a shallow vertical groove which passes from the superior vena cava to inferior vena cava. This groove is called the sulcus terminalis. It is produced by an internal muscular ridge called the Crista terminalis. The upper part of the sulcus contains the sinuatrial or SA node which act as the pacemaker of the heart.

questions.text: All of the following are branches from the marked structure except
questions.solution:
The marked structure is Thoracic sympathetic chain.

It is a ganglionated chain situated one on each side of thoracic vertebral column.

Superiorly it is continuous with cervical part and inferiorly with lumbar part.

The chain bears 12 ganglia corresponding to 12 thoracic nerves.

The first thoracic ganglion fuse with inferior cervical ganglion to form cervicothoracic or stellate ganglion.

The chain crosses the neck of 1st rib, the heads of 2nd to 10th and bodies of 11th and 12th thoracic vertebrae.

Branches:

  1. Lateral branches for limbs and body wall : Each ganglion is connected with its corresponding spinal nerve by two rami, the white and grey rami communicans.
  2. Medial branches:
    • From upper 5 ganglia gives Pulmonary, Cardiac , Aortic and Oesophageal branches.
    • From lower 7 ganglia : Form greater , lesser and least splanchnic nerves.

Key takeawys: The phrenic nerve is a mixed motor and sensory nerve that originates from the anterior rami of the C3-C5 spinal nerves in the neck

questions.text: The neurovascular bundle in the thoracic wall present between
questions.solution:
Intercostal space :

The space between the two adjacent ribs are known as intercostal spaces.

Thus there are 11 intercostal spaces on either side.

Each space contains the following structure :

  • Three intercostal muscles
  • Intercostal nerves
  • Intercostal arteries
  • Intercostal veins
  • Intercostal lymph vessels and lymph nodes

The neurovascular bundle consisting of intercostal nerve and vessels lies between internal intercostal and Intercostalis intimi.

Key takeaways : - The neurovascular bundle are arranged in the following order from above downwards : (Mnemonics : VAN )

  • Intercostal Vein
  • Intercostal Artery
  • Intercostal Nerve

questions.text: All of the following are branches of internal thoracic artery except
questions.solution:
Internal thoracic artery :

  • It arise from the inferior aspect of first part of subclavian artery opposite to thyrocervical trunk.
  • It descends medially and downwards behind the Sternal end of clavicle and 1st costal cartilage.
  • Runs vertically downwards till 6th intercostal space and end by dividing into 2 terminal branches.

Branches :

  • The Pericardiophrenic artery : supplies pericardium and Diaphragm.
  • The Mediastinal arteries : supply Thymus, pericardium and fat in mediastinum.
  • Two anterior intercostal arteries are given in upper 6 intercostal spaces.
  • The perforating branches : accompany the anterior cutaneous nerves
  • The superior epigastric artery : terminal branch that enters the rectus sheath
  • The Musculophrenic artery : gives 2 anterior intercostal branches to 7th to 9th intercostal spaces.

Lateral thoracic artery : is a branch of 2nd part of Axillary artery.

choices.text: It extend from lateral border of sternum to angle of ribs
It arise from the lower border of rib above the space
It inserted on outer lip of upper border of rib below
The direction of fibre is downward, forward and medially

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect for external intercostal muscle ?
questions.solution:
External intercostal muscle :

  • It extends from tubercle of the rib posteriorly to the Costochondral junction anteriorly.
  • Between Costochondral junction sternum , it is replaced by external intercostal membrane.
  • The posterior end of muscle is continuous with the posterior fibres of superior costotransverse ligament.
  • The fibres of external intercostal muscle runs downwards, forwards and medially.
  • Origin : Lower border of the rib above the space
  • Insertion: Outer lip of the upper border of the rib below.
  • Nerve supply : Intercostal nerve
  • Action : To prevent intercostal spaces being drawn in during inspiration and from bulging outwards during expiration.

questions.text: All of the following are contents of posterior mediastinum except
questions.solution:
Posterior Mediastinum:

Boundaries:

  • Anteriorly : Pericardium, bifurcation of trachea, pulmonary vessels,
  • Posteriorly : Lower eight thoracic vertebrae and Intervertebral disc
  • On each side : Mediastinal pleura

Contents:

  • Oesopahgus
  • Arteries: Descending thoracic aorta & its branches
  • Veins: Azygos vein, Hemiazygos vein and Accessory Hemiazygos vein
  • Nerves: Vagus, Splanchnic nerves
  • Lymph nodes: Thoracic duct, Posterior Mediastinal lymph nodes

Key takeaways: thymus is content of anterior mediastinum.

choices.text: There are eleven posterior intercostal artery on each side
The left posterior intercostal arteries are longer than right
3rd to 11th posterior intercostal arteries arise from descending thoracic aorta
Posterior intercostal artery ends by anastomosing with upper anterior intercostal artery of space

questions.text: Which of the following statements are incorrect for Posterior intercostal arteries?
questions.solution:
Posterior intercostal arteries:

There are eleven in number on each side, one in each space.

1st and 2nd posterior intercostal arteries arise from superior intercostal artery which is branch of costocervical trunk

3rd to 11th arteries arise from the descending thoracic aorta.

The right posterior intercostal artery pass behind the oesophagus, thoracic duct, Azygos vein and sympathetic chain. The posterior intercostal arteries pass behind the Hemiazygos vein and sympathetic chain.

Each posterior intercostal artery ends at the level of Costochondral junction by anastomosing with upper anterior intercostal artery of the space.

Key takeaways: The right sided arteries are longer than those of the left side.

questions.text: A 30 years old male came to hospital with complaint of pain and numbness in his right hand and forearm. He experienced pain when he lift his arm or he tilt his head toward opposite side. Chest x ray revealed a bony structure extending from C7 vertebra. What is the most likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Cervical Rib :

The costal element of the C7 vertebra may elongate to form a cervical rib in about 5% individuals.

The condition may be unilateral or bilateral.

It may have a blind tip or tip may be connected to 1st rib by fibrous band or cartilage or bone.

It may compress the lower trunk of brachial plexus and subclavian artery. The compression produces :

  • Pain and numbness along medial side of forearm and hand and wasting of small muscles of hand due to involvement of lower trunk of brachial plexus.
  • Ischemic symptoms in upper limb such as pallor and coldness of upper limb and weak radial pulse due to compression of subclavian artery.

Carpal tunnel syndrome : It is due to compression of median nerve below flexor retinaculum.

Cubital tunnel syndrome : due to compression of ulnar nerve behind the medial epicondyle.

questions.text: All of the following nerves are present within superior mediastinum except
questions.solution:
Superior Mediastinum:

The mediastinum is the middle space left in the thoracic cavity in between the lungs.

The superior mediastinum is separated from the inferior by an imaginary plane by passing through the Sternal angle (anteriorly) and lower border of T4 vertebra ( posteriorly).

Boundaries:

  • Anteriorly : Manubrium sterni
  • Posteriorly : Upper four thoracic vertebrae
  • Superiorly : Plane of thoracic inlet
  • Inferiorly : Imaginary plane
  • On each side : Mediastinal pleura

Contents:

  • Trachea and Oesophagus
  • Muscles : Sternohyoid, Sternothyroid, Longus colli
  • Arteries : Arch of aorta, brachiocephalic artery, left common carotid artery,
  • Veins : Right and left brachiocephalic vein, Upper part of superior vena cava
  • Nerves : Vagus, Phrenic, Cardiac nerves, Left recurrent laryngeal nerves
  • Thymus
  • Thoracic duct

Lymph nodes: Paratracheal, brachiocephalic and Tracheobronchial

questions.text: Which of the following occurs during normal quiet expiration?
questions.solution:
Respiratory movements during different types of breathing :

Quiet Inspiration :

  • The anteroposterior diameter of thorax is increased by elevation of 2nd to 6th ribs.
  • The transverse diameter is increased by elevation of 7th to 10th rib.
  • The vertical diameter is increased by descent of diaphragm.

Deep Inspiration :

  • Movements during quiet inspiration are increased
  • The first rib is elevated by scaleni
  • The concavity of thoracic spine is reduced by erector spinae.

Forced Inspiration:

  • All above movements are exaggerated.
  • The scapulae are elevated and fixed by trapezius, levator scapulae so that serratus anterior and pectoralis minor may act on the ribs
  • The action of erector spinae is also increased

Quiet Expiration :

  • The air expelled by elastic recoil of the chest wall and alveoli and partly by tone of abdominal muscles

Deep and forced expiration :

  • Strong contraction of abdominal muscles and of latissimus dorsi.

Key takeaway: Respiratory movements range from increasing thoracic diameters during inspiration to relying on elastic recoil and abdominal muscle contraction during expiration, with variations in intensity depending on the type of breathing.

questions.text: Cardiac tamponade is the condition that occur due to
questions.solution:
Pericarditis and cardiac tamponade:

The inflammation of the serous pericardium is called Pericarditis which causes accumulation of serous fluid in pericardial cavity, the pericardial effusion.

The excessive accumulation of serous fluid in pericardial cavity may compress the thin walled atria and interfere with the filling of the heart during diastole and consequently the cardiac output is diminished. This condition is clinically termed cardiac tamponade.

Pericardiocentesis: Excessive pericardial fluid can be aspirated from the pericardial cavity by two routes:

  • Sternal approach: The needle is inserted through the left 5th or 6th intercostal space immediately adjacent to sternum.
  • Subxiphoid approach: The needle is inserted in the left costo xiphoid angle and passed in an upward and backward direction at an angle of 45 to the skin.

Blockage of coronary arteries leads to myocardial ischemia followed by myocardial necrosis.

Angina Pectoris: Incomplete obstruction, usually due to spasm of coronary artery associate with agonising pain in the pre cordial region and down the medial side of left arm and forearm.

Myocarditis: Inflammation of myocardium is called Myocarditis. Myocarditis can cause chest pain, shortness of breath, and rapid or irregular heartbeats.
